title: ABC Score for Massive Transfusion
description: Predicts the necessity for massive transfusion in trauma patients using clinical variables available at initial assessment

parameters.name: penetrating_mechanism
parameters.description: Presence of penetrating mechanism of injury (gunshot wound, stab wound, etc.)

parameters.name: systolic_bp_90_or_less
parameters.description: Systolic blood pressure ≤90 mmHg in the Emergency Department

parameters.name: heart_rate_120_or_more
parameters.description: Heart rate ≥120 beats per minute in the Emergency Department

parameters.name: positive_fast
parameters.description: Positive FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) ultrasound examination

result.name: abc_score
result.description: ABC Score for predicting massive transfusion requirement

ranges.description: Less likely to require massive transfusion
ranges.interpretation: Patient is less likely to require massive transfusion, defined as ≥10 units of packed red blood cells in the first 24 hours of resuscitation. Standard trauma resuscitation protocols should be followed.

Patient is likely to require massive transfusion, defined as ≥10 units of packed red blood cells in the first 24 hours of resuscitation. Immediate activation of massive transfusion protocol (MTP) is recommended.

references: Nunez TC, Voskresensky IV, Dossett LA, et al. Early prediction of massive transfusion in trauma: simple as ABC (assessment of blood consumption)? J Trauma. 2009;66(2):346-52. doi: 10.1097/TA.0b013e3181961c35.
Cotton BA, Dossett LA, Haut ER, et al. Multicenter validation of a simplified score to predict massive transfusion in trauma. J Trauma. 2010;69 Suppl 1:S33-9. doi: 10.1097/TA.0b013e3181e42411.
formula: ABC Score = (Penetrating mechanism: 1 if yes, 0 if no) + (Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg: 1 if yes, 0 if no) + (Heart rate ≥120 bpm: 1 if yes, 0 if no) + (Positive FAST: 1 if yes, 0 if no)
notes: ABC stands for Assessment of Blood Consumption
A score of ≥2 has sensitivity of 75% and specificity of 86% for predicting massive transfusion
Negative predictive value is 97% and positive predictive value is 55%
Massive transfusion is defined as ≥10 units of packed red blood cells in first 24 hours
The score uses only clinical variables available at initial assessment, no laboratory values required
Designed for use in early trauma resuscitation to activate massive transfusion protocols
